hypothesis.name: Mid-range Tilt and Azimuth
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt of around 30° is often optimal for solar panels in temperate regions, while an azimuth of 180° (south-facing) maximizes exposure to sunlight throughout the day.

hypothesis.name: High Tilt for Winter Optimization
hypothesis.rationale: A higher tilt angle of 60° can be beneficial in winter months to capture lower sun angles, combined with a south-facing azimuth.

hypothesis.name: Low Tilt for Summer Optimization
hypothesis.rationale: A lower tilt angle of 15° can be effective in summer to maximize energy capture when the sun is high in the sky, with an azimuth of 180°.

hypothesis.name: East-West Orientation
hypothesis.rationale: Setting the azimuth to 90° (east) and 270° (west) with a moderate tilt can help capture morning and evening sunlight, potentially increasing total daily energy production.

hypothesis.name: Balanced Capacity and Ratio
hypothesis.rationale: A balanced approach with a system capacity of 5 kW and a DC to AC ratio of 1.5 can optimize energy conversion efficiency while maintaining system performance.

hypothesis.name: High Tilt and South-Southwest Azimuth
hypothesis.rationale: Exploring higher tilt angles around 75° with a south-southwest azimuth has shown promising results in maximizing energy output.

hypothesis.name: Higher Tilt with Slight Azimuth Variation
hypothesis.rationale: Testing a tilt of 80° with a slight variation in azimuth (around 180°) could further optimize energy capture based on previous results.

hypothesis.name: Moderate Tilt with High Capacity
hypothesis.rationale: A moderate tilt of 70° with maximum system capacity (20 kW) may balance energy capture and system performance effectively.

hypothesis.name: Exploring Lower Tilt with Higher Capacity
hypothesis.rationale: Testing a lower tilt of 60° with maximum capacity could reveal if there's a sweet spot for energy production at this configuration.

hypothesis.name: East-West Orientation with High Capacity
hypothesis.rationale: Revisiting east-west orientations with a tilt of 70° and high capacity may yield insights into capturing morning and evening sunlight.

hypothesis.name: Optimal Tilt and Azimuth
hypothesis.rationale: Continuing to explore a tilt of 70u00b0 with a south-facing azimuth has shown the highest energy outputs, indicating this is a sweet spot for energy production.

hypothesis.name: Higher Tilt Exploration
hypothesis.rationale: Testing a tilt of 75u00b0 with a south-facing azimuth could further optimize energy capture based on previous results.

hypothesis.rationale: A moderate tilt of 68u00b0 with maximum system capacity (20 kW) may balance energy capture and system performance effectively.

hypothesis.rationale: Testing a tilt of 65u00b0 with maximum capacity could reveal if there's a sweet spot for energy production at this configuration.
